257. Buckingham, Nellie (Mrs. John George)
Mrs. J. F. Buckingham
Address: Millington, Kent, England

1. HOUSEHOLD HISTORY
   - What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? 1910
   - Where did you get your housekeeping? Millington, Kent
   - Where had you been living before that? Hurley, Surrey, England
   - For how many people did you prepare meals? 2
   - How far was it to your nearest store? 6 miles
   - How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a month
   - What groceries did you usually buy in those earlier years? Flour, tea, salt, sugar, rolled oats, prunes, beans, raisins, baking powder, soda, soap, syrup, jam, yeast

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
   - What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Heathley Bell
   - In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs. per bag
   - What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $3.50
   - How much did you use groats flour?
   - How much wheat flour? 60 lbs.
   - Was flour milled locally? No
   - How far away? 20 miles
   - What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? About
   - What other grain products did you use?
     - Corn meal
     - Whole wheat
     - Farina
   - Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
   - How did you grind it?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

Butter? Home made.

Did you make butter? Yes.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Beef in winter, pork in summer.

How did you get fresh meat? When one farmer butchered, neighbor bought part of same.

How often did you get fresh meat? Not often.

How did you preserve meat? None.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Yes.

What kinds? Pheasant, chicken, ducks.

For how long? Several years.

What part did fish play in the family diet? When we had time to fish in the Meeting Lake.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh.

Kinds? Jack fish, sometimes white fish.

Peas? Corn? Beans? Saskatoons? Other foods?

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Canning
To what extent? About 125 to 200 quarts

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Range larger with reservoir, more utensils to use, canned goods, purchasing yeast for bread making, a better variety of goods purchased in the store.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

We still use home grown & home prepared foods as well as those we purchase.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

In the early days we used to take our wheat into the flour mill & trade for flour, bran, shorts etc.

Sometimes neighbors would bring our groceries from the store or sometimes we went to Eaton's for goods such as prunes, raisins, jams etc. We had to go 50 miles to North Battleford to get them as that was our nearest town.

In the fall we would make up a large order for Eaton's & the mail man would bring it from N. Battleford by road. In 1916 a cream route was started & farmers would take their turn to haul cream to North Battleford during the summer leaving about 8 p.m. so that the cream would keep cool during the night.
21. Would you rather to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home grown? (Give as many details as possible.)

We still use some garden produce and canned goods as well as those we purchase.

22. Plans and other details. (Describe your family's experiences of buying groceries and supplies. Include items not mentioned above, such as quality, quantity, prices, problems encountered, etc.)

In the early days we used to take our wheel in to the store mill for flour, sugar, etc., and sometimes neighbors would bring our grist from the other side of town. We also got our goods from the store mill, which was about five miles away. In the fall we would make up a large order for flour, sugar, etc., and the mail man would bring it from N. Battleford by road. In 1916 a new route was started to North Battleford during the winter, and cream was delivered at night. The summer delivery was made during the day.
